newsitem.title: USA: Minneapolis Fed's Stern says economy well balanced.
newsitem.headline: Minneapolis Fed's Stern says economy well balanced.

text.p: Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Gary Stern said the U.S. economy appears positioned for well-balanced growth in the coming year, though he noted tight labor markets and creeping wage growth.
"The economy appears well-positioned for another year of balanced growth," said Stern in a speech to a Minneapolis Fed community conference.
But Stern reiterated a commonly-held Fed position that monetary policy must be geared toward future economic events and look past current conditions.

"If you wait until everybody agrees that there is a serious inflation problem, you're going to find it's very hard to deal with that problem and you're going to pay probably a high price in terms of economic performance," said Stern.
That pre-emptive approach to fighting inflation justified the Fed's quarter-point hike in the federal funds rate last Tuesday, Stern added.
"I think this action has the promise of sustaining the kind of positive economic times we have enjoyed for some time now," he added.
Scattered U.S. labor shortages and mild wage inflation also help explain the Fed's need to tighten credit at last week's meeting, Stern continued.
"I don't think there's much question that many labor markets are very tight, you can see that by the measured unemployment rates," he said.
Dwindling labor supply has already begun to boost Americans' wages, Stern noted.

"As a matter of fact, you do see some upcreep there. So there has been some acceleration of wages. Now, I'm not suggesting that's bad. I'm simply stating that as a fact," the regional Fed president added.
